rev.diff:
Line 220: Line 220:
===2012 presidential candidacy===
===2012 presidential candidacy===
â
Trump has said that he is seriously considering running for [[President of the United States]] in [[United States presidential election, 2012|the 2012 election]].<ref>Madison, Lucy (October 4, 2010) [http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-503544_162-20018405-503544.html "Donald Trump for President in 2012?"], CBS News. Retrieved October 4, 2010.</ref><ref>Zwick, Jesse (October 4, 2010) [http://washingtonindependent.com/99472/donald-trump-for-president "Donald Trump for President?"], The Washington Independent. Retrieved October 4, 2010.</ref> In his [[Republican Party (United States) presidential primaries, 2012|primary campaign]], Trump has made a February speech to a [[Conservative Political Action Conference|CPAC]] gathering,<ref name="thall11">{{cite web|url=http://townhall.com/tipsheet/katiepavlich/2011/02/10/crowd_goes_wild_over_donald_trump_speech_at_cpac|title=Crowd Goes Wild Over Donald Trump Speech at CPAC|publisher=[[Townhall.com]]|date=February 10, 2011|accessdate=2011-02-11}}</ref> an early venue for candidates considering a presidential run, as a write-in candidate in its [[straw poll]] for the office. A Wall Street Journal/NBC News poll released in March 2011 found Donald Trump leading among potential contenders for the Republican nomination for President of the United States, one point ahead of former Massachusetts Governor [[Mitt Romney]].<ref>Haberman, Maggie (March 7, 2011).[http://www.nbcnewyork.com/news/politics/Trump_tops_Romney__Pawlenty-117496043.html Trump tops Romney, Pawlenty]. ''NBC New York''. Retrieved March 7, 2011.</ref> A Newsweek poll conducted February 2011 showed Trump within a few points of Obama, with many voters undecided in the November 2012 general election for President of the United States against [[Barack Obama]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/blogs-and-stories/2011-02-21/obama-hits-50-percent-approval-rating-according-to-new-newsweekdaily-beast-poll/?cid=hp:beastoriginalsL2|title=Obama Hits 50 Percent Approval Rating, According to New Newsweek/Daily Beast Poll|publisher=The Newsweek / Daily Beast Company LLC|first=Douglas|last=Schoen|date=February 21, 2011|accessdate=April 14, 2011}}</ref> A poll released in April 2011 by Public Policy Polling showed Trump having a nine point lead in a potential contest for the Republican nomination for President of the United States.<ref>Shadid, Aliyah (April 15, 2011).[http://www.nydailynews.com/news/politics/2011/04/15/2011-04-15_donald_trump_takes_lead_in_gop_primary_poll_beats_romney_huckabee_palin_gingrich.html?r=news/politics Donald Trump takes lead in GOP primary poll, beats Romney, Huckabee, Palin, Gingrich, Bachmann, Paul].''New York Daily News''. Retrieved April 17, 2011.</ref>
+
Trump has said that he is seriously considering running for [[President of the United States]] in [[United States presidential election, 2012|the 2012 election]].<ref>Madison, Lucy (October 4, 2010) [http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-503544_162-20018405-503544.html "Donald Trump for President in 2012?"], CBS News. Retrieved October 4, 2010.</ref><ref>Zwick, Jesse (October 4, 2010) [http://washingtonindependent.com/99472/donald-trump-for-president "Donald Trump for President?"], The Washington Independent. Retrieved October 4, 2010.</ref> In his [[Republican Party (United States) presidential primaries, 2012|primary campaign]], Trump has made a February speech to a [[Conservative Political Action Conference|CPAC]] gathering,<ref name="thall11">{{cite web|url=http://townhall.com/tipsheet/katiepavlich/2011/02/10/crowd_goes_wild_over_donald_trump_speech_at_cpac|title=Crowd Goes Wild Over Donald Trump Speech at CPAC|publisher=[[Townhall.com]]|date=February 10, 2011|accessdate=2011-02-11}}</ref> an early venue for candidates considering a presidential run, as a write-in candidate in its [[straw poll]] for the office. A Wall Street Journal/NBC News poll released in March 2011 found Donald Trump leading among potential contenders for the Republican nomination for President of the United States, one point ahead of former Massachusetts Governor [[Mitt Romney]].<ref>Haberman, Maggie (March 7, 2011).[http://www.nbcnewyork.com/news/politics/Trump_tops_Romney__Pawlenty-117496043.html Trump tops Romney, Pawlenty]. ''NBC New York''. Retrieved March 7, 2011.</ref> A Newsweek poll conducted February 2011 showed Trump within a few points of Obama, with many voters undecided in the November 2012 general election for President of the United States against [[Barack Obama]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/blogs-and-stories/2011-02-21/obama-hits-50-percent-approval-rating-according-to-new-newsweekdaily-beast-poll/?cid=hp:beastoriginalsL2|title=Obama Hits 50 Percent Approval Rating, According to New Newsweek/Daily Beast Poll|publisher=The Newsweek / Daily Beast Company LLC|first=Douglas|last=Schoen|date=February 21, 2011|accessdate=April 14, 2011}}</ref> A poll released in April 2011 by Public Policy Polling showed Trump having a nine point lead in a potential contest for the Republican nomination for President of the United States.<ref>Shadid, Aliyah (April 15, 2011).[http://www.nydailynews.com/news/politics/2011/04/15/2011-04-15_donald_trump_takes_lead_in_gop_primary_poll_beats_romney_huckabee_palin_gingrich.html?r=news/politics Donald Trump takes lead in GOP primary poll, beats Romney, Huckabee, Palin, Gingrich, Bachmann, Paul].''New York Daily News''. Retrieved April 17, 2011.</ref> Trump's popularity among Republicans was shortlived, however, as a May 10 poll found him tied with Ron Paul for fifth place among Republicans.<ref> [http://www.publicpolicypolling.com/pdf/PPP_Release_US_0510925.pdf Public Policy Polling]</ref>
Trump's present political stances include the following:<ref>{{cite web|author=Nikki Schwab and Katy Adams |url=http://washingtonexaminer.com/blogs/yeas-nays/2011/02/trump-makes-case-oval-office-upsets-paul-supporters |title=Trump makes a case for the Oval Office, upsets Paul supporters | Nikki Schwab | Yeas & Nays |publisher=Washington Examiner |date= |accessdate=2011-04-21}}</ref>
Trump's present political stances include the following:<ref>{{cite web|author=Nikki Schwab and Katy Adams |url=http://washingtonexaminer.com/blogs/yeas-nays/2011/02/trump-makes-case-oval-office-upsets-paul-supporters |title=Trump makes a case for the Oval Office, upsets Paul supporters | Nikki Schwab | Yeas & Nays |publisher=Washington Examiner |date= |accessdate=2011-04-21}}</ref>
